turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Tentative my foot -- a month before this your old father-in-law came very privately and scratched at my door.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Scratched --  We did not take the initiative.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Of course you took the initiative.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I know you did -- I said you did --

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: And I said we didn't.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Evil days -- I've shown you here --  -- my company exports to the Balkans alone, sixty-five thousand marks worth of mop rags a year.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Mop rags -- mop rags -- we're interested in something quite different!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Sorry, Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You've decided against the merger?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Yes --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Then, it's all over?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Yes --

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull through. This is a very bad time to be in such a crisis. We've...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Why talk -- it's over -- it's over -- it's finished. You've broken off negotiations. You did it. You're calling them off. You had nothing on your mind all day, but Manchester, -- Manchester -- Manchester.  You don't suppose for one moment that I'm such a fool as not to have something that I could say definitely about Manchester.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Oh no -- no -- the session is over. Let's go, it's off. Thank you, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: If you actually have news from Manchester then...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Gentlemen, I am now free to announce...  ...that the deal between my firm and the Manchester Cotton Company has been successfully negotiated.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Preysing, you're joking with us.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I thought we'd suspended negotiations, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Under these circumstances it's quite a different matter.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Under these circumstances we might refuse to sign.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: See you soon, Preysing. Next week we'll meet and discuss further details.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Next week.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: How clear is Manchester?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Foggy -- frightfully foggy, always, I'm told.  Have you said anything about Manchester, Mr. Preysing?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Since, on the eleventh of June of this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger...

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Thank God we're beginning at the beginning.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: As you remember it -- when you approached us...

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: We did not approach you.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: ...and let me say again for the tenth time...  ...you people were quite ready for the merger. You declared yourselves... fully agreed on all the terms -- Why should the signing of these articles be suddenly held up?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: I've admitted that at one time we had reason for desiring ther merger -- What reason have we now? The Preysing Company has fallon upon evil days, very evil days.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Mr. Preysing has too scrupulous a regard for certainties...

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: You've talked enough today, you're hoarse now.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Here's my signature -- here Preysing, sign here.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: What a session this has been.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Nine-thirty, Mr. Preysing keeps us waiting.

turns.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
turns.text: He likes to play the great man.

turns.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
turns.text: Shall I tell them again?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Why waste time -- it's getting late.

turns.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
turns.text: You see -- what we are interested in --

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Ah, come on -- we're going home.

turns.speaker: SCHWEIMANN
turns.text: You're a deep one.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: In that case give us the articles. We'll sign at once. We know all the details...

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Always the performance -- every day the performance -- time for the performance.  I think, Suzette, I have never been so tired in my life.  Veronal didn't even help me to sleep.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car is to be brought.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I can't dance tonight --

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: It will pass -- it will pass -- come.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Let us cancel the engagement.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: But, Madam. cannot do that.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Now is the time to cancel to stop entirely. I feel it -- everything tells me -- enough -- enough.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Mon Dieu -- the pearls -- if they were to break --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: The pearls won't break -- they hold together and bring me bad luck ---- I hate them!

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Orchids come again, Madam -- no card -- I think perhaps they are from the same young man -- he is at the end of the corridor -- tall -- he walks like a soldier -- Madam must have noticed how often he is in the elevator with us. Last night for instance --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh, Suzette -- Suzette -- Sshh -- quiet.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Ah, oui -- the car is here for Madam.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Send it away -- I shan't need it.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Oh, come, Madam -- please come.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: All right, Suzette -- quickly -- hurry.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Good morning, Suzette.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Good morning, Madam.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Madam has slept well?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh, yes, Suzette.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Madam will dress now, it is late.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Five minutes, Suzette, come back in five minutes. I'll ring.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Yes, madam Suzette knows all about it.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Madam should sleep.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I've done my hair differently -- do you like that?

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: When a lady falls in love she does her hair differently.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: In the middle of the night -- those flowers make me think of a funeral. Laurels and tube-roses.  Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple -- happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep. It is not long 'till the train.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Goodnight, Suzette.

turns.speaker: SUZETTE
turns.text: Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is waiting downstairs.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov?

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: What is this that you have cancelled your car? Who am I that I should wait like a fool at the door? And here on a whim, you cancel your car. Have you forgotten there is a performance? Do you know the time? Or, are we all mad? Am I your manager?... Have we a contract? Have we obligations? Am I blind?  ...Or is that the time?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I'm cancelling the engagement.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Oh! Madam is cancelling the engagement. Madam has chosen a funny time for such a funny joke. Ha, ha, ha -- hurry, come on. Tonight -- there's a line in front of the theatre since six o'clock. The house is jammed to the roof.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: The house is not full -- Is it really full?

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Packed to the ceiling. Hurry -- get dressed. And what an audience -- the French Ambassador -- American Millionaires -- Princess Ratzville -- er -- er --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh -- but it can't be.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Suzette -- I told you not to bring the pearls. I will not wear them tonight.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Take them back, Suzette.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: You haven't time.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Hurry, Suzette.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Such nonsense.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: I suppose I can cancel the Vienna engagement.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I wish to be alone.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: You'll be very much alone, my dear madame. This is the end.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Come along, oh, Madam, come along. The train will be going.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in Tremezzo --

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Every seat for the opening has been sold at Vienna. Sold out for three days.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I know -- I know -- but it will be sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest then.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: It is time for the performance.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: The performance -- the performance -- the performance.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: It is not stage fright -- it's something more --

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: What -- what is it? Last night...

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Last night?... There was no applause.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: There was -- there was.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: That theatre -- half empty -- dancing for those few -- I was frantic -- I finished -- the last beat and...  ...I waited -- I listened -- but the applause didn't come -- nothing. A man in the box -- and just the claques behind -- it is passed, Pimenov. We are dead -- it's finished.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Good morning, Pimenov.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Good morning, Gru -- your --

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Gru -- you are positively radiant.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Yes, Pimenov.  One minute, Suzette, I will call you.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: He will be on the train.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: But when did he go? How do you know?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Mr. Kringelein will take room number one-seventy-six, one of our most expensive rooms. It is large and on the front with bath.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Does that mean that the bath is my own? --- Private?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Certainly, sir.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Well, now, that's very kind -- thanks. That's what I want -- a large room on the front with a private bath -- Yes, that's what I want. I can pay now if you like.

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Will Mr. Kringelein kindly register.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Again?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I wish you a very good evening, Mr. Preysing. You are staying here, too, Mr. Preysing?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I don't know you.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- you must know me -- Kringelein at the plant. Assistant bookkeeper, building C, room twenty-three -- third floor.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend and not accept your invitation to dance.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I could not think of not accepting.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You say that you are employed by us in Fredersdorf, and here you are in Berlin, indulging in diversions which ill befit your position and which are very much beyond your means -- Quite extraordinary, Mr. Kringelein, I think we will look into your books.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You may go, Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Does the world belong to you, Mr. Preysing?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What is this insolence?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Do you think you have free license to be insulting? Believe me you have not. You think you're superior, but you're quite an ordinary man.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Go away -- go away.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Who are you? -- An embezzler most likely.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: An embezzler -- you're going to take that back, right here in the presence of this young lady -- who do you think you're talking to? You think I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You're discharged.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get out -- you're discharged.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: My best friend -- poor, Baron -- dead -- just like that.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: -- We must do something...

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes, the police must be called.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a burglar -- he was going to steal my money.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Where is that girl -- she was working with him -- she enticed me into her room.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing -- I understand, Mr. General Director Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this -- but that girl -- the scandal -- my wife -- my daughters, you know them?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes, I know them --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: The scandal -- we are men -- you -- you could take that affair of the young lady upon yourself -- take her and hold your tongue. Then you can travel -- I'll give you anything -- anything -- she was with you.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: We must call the police, your excellency.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: How much -- how much do you want -- you need money -- you have nothing.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Don't worry about me, Mr. General Director Pryesing -- worry about yourself.  There has been a murder -- this is room one sixty-four.

turns.speaker: ROHNA
turns.text: If you will wait one moment, sir.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I won't wait -- I can't wait -- I waited three days before I got a room at all and what a room that is.

turns.speaker: ROHNA
turns.text: It's a very nice room and inexpensive, sir.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Did I say I wanted a cheap room to live in -- when I came here did I ask for a cheap room? Did I?

turns.speaker: ROHNA
turns.text: Just one moment, sir.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: No, I won't wait -- I can't -- Every day is precious -- every hour -- Every minute.

turns.speaker: ROHNA
turns.text: The gentleman is dissatisfied with room number five fifty-nine.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I certainly have a complaint -- and a fair one.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: We will wait.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: You are late. Hurry.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: How is the house?

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Terrible. After this, no more ballets for me. Jazz --  Just jazz.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: If the house is empty again, I don't know --

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: When she gets her paint on and hears the music -- she'll be all right. I know these people.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: What's the use of asking, Gru -- he is at the train -- He will be there.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: The troupe, the scenery, everything -- all on board, waiting. You have a rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning. Come, Madam, are you mad?

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Four minutes past. Please come.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there -- he will be there.

turns.speaker: MEIERHEIM
turns.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Ach! Here you are, Doctor Zinnowitz.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Have I kept you waiting?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Waiting -- I'm waiting for news from Manchester.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: No news yet?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No. No word.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Everything depends on the Manchester merger.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I know -- I know.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: I saw Gerstenkorn at lunch -- and as your lawyer I made it my business to broach the matter ---

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No news from Manchester yet -- Do you think we ought to postpone the conference?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Good heavens no. That'd create the very worst impression. You must be optimistic. You must convince them. You know as well as I do that the merger must go through.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Yes -- the merger must go through -- But I am used to making my deals on a solid basis. I am not a liar. I am an honest business man -- a good husband and father -- I have a sense of honor -- I have nothing to conceal. I couldn't live happily otherwise.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Well, don't get excited about it. We agreed that the merger with the Saxonia people must go through.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I want to dictate my statement for tomorrow. I can't speak without notes. I like to have things down before me in black and white.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: I'll see you in the morning then, at the conference. Everything'll be all right, Preysing... Don't worry. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Good morning, gentlemen -- I see the conference is already underway.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Oh, here you are, Justice Zinnowitz -- I'm at cross-purposes with these gentlemen -- will you clear up the situation?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: But the situation is perfectly clear, If you will allow me --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I can make no statement about Manchester at this time.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Well -- gentlemen.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Next week.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: You let me talk till I'm hoarse and you had Manchester sewed-up all the time. Why?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: What's bluff?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: That.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: 'Deal with Manchester definitely off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have thought it of you.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No one would have thought it of me. I've been getting rusty in Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what the world wants I guess I can put up as big a bluff as anyone. From now on...

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: You must go to Manchester at once yourself and really see it through.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was desperate -- Now I don't care -- This sort of thing goes to a man's head.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: What you need is some relaxation.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd like to tear loose -- I'd like a drink. I'd like to go down to that dancing place. I'd like to start something.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: I can understand that -- after your -- uh --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's the first time in thirty years that I've ever... Where's that stenographer? Miss Flaemm...

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: What do you want with her?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I want to see her, I want to do some dictating -- report of the conference for my father-in-law.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: She had an engagement in the Yellow Room at five o'clock -- she was in a hurry.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Zinnowitz, would you say she was pretty?

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Pretty as a picture.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Let's go down and find her -- I need a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz.  I don't know anything about women -- been married for twenty-six years.

turns.speaker: ZINNOWITZ
turns.text: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does it. Goodnight.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Hi, Bobo.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Did I buy you that dress, you piece of shit?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well, I guess so. You're the guy I work for.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You work for me, huh? Then I just may flush you down the toilet. Drive me to the Durando.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: How'd you figure you were gonna get away with that?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I'm not getting away with anything, Bobo.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You're fuckin right you're not. How much did your pals cut you in for on that nag, huh? Or did they give you the same kind of screwing you gave me?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I was down on that horse, Bobo. Not as much as I should have been, but there was a lot of action on those--

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I want to keep my teeth.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. There ain't enough action to tickle the tote, but you claim a ten grand win! You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Bobo, no, I --

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You wanna talk to me straight up?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: My son --

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Your what?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: My son was in the hospital --

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: What the fuck are you doin with a son?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: He left home a long time ago. He was in the hospital, up in Los Ang gleez, real sick.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Motherhood.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I never fucked up before, Bobo.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You expect me to buy this?

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: I got a lot of people work for me, Lilly. I can't have shit like this.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: It'll never happen again. I swear.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: It happened once. With me, that's making a habit of it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You're calling the shots.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You got any kind of long coat in the car? Anything you can wear home over your clothes?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: I'll loan you a raincoat.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You ever hear about the oranges?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You mean, the insurance frammis?

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Tell me about the oranges, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You hit a person with the oranges in the towel, they get big, awful looking bruises, but they don't really get hurt, not if you do it right. It's for working scams against insurance companies.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: And if you do it wrong?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: It can louse up your insides. You can get puh, puh, puh...

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: What's that, Lilly?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Permanent damage.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You'll never shit right again.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Almost forgot. That ten grand of yours. It's in the envelope by the door.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Oh, thanks, Bobo.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You want a drink?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Gee, I better not, if it's okay. I still gotta drive back up to Los Ang-gleez.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: See your son, huh? Well, that's nice. A side of you I didn't know, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: He's a good kid. A salesman.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: On the square, huh? And how are you making out these days? Stealing much?

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: That's right. Take a little, leave a little.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You're a thousand percent right!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: You know it, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well, you can tell them I said they're right.  I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.

turns.speaker: BOBO
turns.text: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I will. So long, Bobo.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Your kid's in the back here. He's crying.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy? He's always crying.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The kids beat him up, because his home life is, uh, different.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I like you, too.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Come on, kid, let's see if there's any food in the house.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Hah.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Evening. Welcome to Phoenix.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Good evening. I'd like a single for tonight.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Oh, everything's the same size, same price.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I'm a very light sleeper, traffic noise keeps me wide awake all night.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Those trucks. I know exactly what you mean.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Do you have something around back, facing away from the road?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: I'll put you in one thirty-one. Very quiet. Faces the desert.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Sounds perfect. I can park my car back there?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Right in front of the room.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: And I'll want to leave an early wake-up call.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: No problem. My husband gets up the crack of dawn.  It's his kidneys.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Mary Beth, what we have here, uh...

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, I told Mister Hebbing all about it, how brilliant you are at making money for your special clients!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Mary Beth, I hope you aren't spreading this good news too widely.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Well, of course not! I know how dangerous this is. But I would trust Mister Hebbing with anything.  Wouldn't I, darling?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Well, I'll have to take your word for it, Mary Beth. Here's your money.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Goody!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Henry, next time, couldn't Mister Hebbing --

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Mary Beth! This has never been anything but --

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, I know, I know, and you've been wonderful since I was widowed. But Mister Hebbing has--  -- you don't mind my telling him, darling --  -- suffered reverses. If he could...

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Well. If Mary Beth vouches for you, and if she told you the story already...

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: So here we are!

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Mister Hebbing, we are talking about breaking the law here, I want to be sure you understand that. No one gets hurt, but the law does get broken.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Want a look?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, Henry, no, that's just boring.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Come take a look. An entire-suite of main-frame computer.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: We're not really interested, Henry.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You ruined me! You destroyed me!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Henry, no!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Cole, it'll be all right. Honey?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Can't move.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: It's just the strain again, the stress. We'll take a vacation.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: It's all hollow. Nothing behind it.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Demon! Demon! That's why you can walk on it! Demon!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, Cole, please. Please come out of it. What would I do without you?

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: Well, that's what the law's for, isn't it?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: And I don't just mean the SEC. We could have the FBI breathing down our necks.

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: I certainly hope not.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Loose talk is the one thing I worry about.

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: I can keep my mouth shut, Mister Fellowes.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: The Tokyo Exchange is nine hours ahead of us, New York one hour behind. There isn't one hour of the day when both are open. Information moves, but it has to wait. Now, we have a young fellow working here -- Do you know what a hacker is, Mister Hebbing?

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: One of those computer geniuses, isn't it?

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You're right! And this boy tapped into that main link between Tokyo and the New York Stock Exchange. He can give us, when it's really useful, a seven second delay in that movement of information. Do you know what that means?

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Every once in a while, a major change comes through. We have seven seconds to take advantage, put our buy order, our sell order, into the computer in New York before the Tokyo data comes in.

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: Not much time.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: These machines -- They're in here.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: Here you are! Two rich people!

turns.speaker: HEBBING
turns.text: I must admit, Mister Fellowes, I had moments I was worried.

turns.speaker: COLE
turns.text: You brought a case? Good.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The ambulance is on the way, for what good it will do.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: What? He's going to be all right!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Mrs. Dillon, your son was in some sort of accident. He's had an internal hemorrhage, he's bleeding to death inside.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well, make it stop!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: His blood pressure is under a hundred. I don't think he'll live to get to the hospital.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You know who I work for.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes, yes, but that's --

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed.

turns.speaker: IRV
turns.text: Bobo wants you to go on to Delmar.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Delmar? I never go out to California. That's a thousand miles from here.

turns.speaker: IRV
turns.text: Nine hundred. Bobo needs somebody to handle playback this time. Come on, Lilly, you don't argue with Bobo.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: IRV
turns.text: Take two, three days. Call when you get there.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Maybe I'll swing around Los Ang gleez on the way.

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: Mrs. Langtry, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Why? What's wrong?

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: You are a valued customer, as you know.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: But what's wrong?

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: But they must be! They cut glass!

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: It was a gift. It isn't worth anything at all?

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: Why, of course it is. I can offer you -- well, five hundred dollars.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: I'll get you a check.

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: It's not your fault.

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I have only one thing now. Are you interested?

turns.speaker: JEWELER
turns.text: Well, I'd have to see it, of course.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Whadaya say?

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Kaggs. Home office.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Roy Dillon.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: I know that. Knew it when I saw you out there. The best salesman here, which isn't saying much. Want to talk to you, Dillon.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That was a pretty backhanded compliment. If I let people get away with things like that, I wouldn't be a good salesman.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: You're right. I apologize. But I still want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Lead on.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: So I heard.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Just myself.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think?
